item.title: A note on Venakides1989 paper about continuum limit of theta functions
item.description:
Claim 1: For any $f\in \mathcal{H}$, there is $m_\epsilon\in \mathbb{Z}^{N(\epsilon)}$, such that \begin{align*} \Phi_\epsilon(m_\epsilon)\rightarrow \Phi(f),\quad \text{as $\epsilon\rightarrow 0$}. \end{align*}

Proof: Since $f\in \mathcal{H}\subset L^2[0,1]$, it can be uniformly approximated by a rational valued simple function. Without loss of generality, we assume $f$ is a rational valued simple function, and define it as \begin{align} f(\eta)=p_\sigma+\frac{\alpha_\sigma}{d_\sigma},\quad \eta \in (\xi_\sigma,\xi_{\sigma+1}),\quad \sigma=1,…,M, \end{align} where $(0,1]=\bigsqcup_{\sigma=1}^M(\xi_\sigma,\xi_{\sigma+1}]$, and $p_\sigma,0\leq \alpha_\sigma<d_\sigma$ are all integers. For such $f$, and fix $\epsilon$, we construct the vector in $\mathbb{Z}^{N(\epsilon)}$ as follows: \begin{align} m_j=\begin{cases} p_\sigma+1 \text{ at the first $\alpha$ indices of $J_\sigma$},\\ p_\sigma \text{ at the next $d_\sigma-\alpha$ indices of $J_\sigma$}, \end{cases} \end{align} where the index set $J_\sigma=\{j|\eta_j\in (\xi_\sigma,\xi_{\sigma+1})\}.$ Now we construct a function $f_\epsilon$ in the following way: \begin{align} f_\epsilon(\eta)=m_j,\quad \eta\in [\frac{1}{2}(\eta_{j+1}+\eta_{j}),\frac{1}{2}(\eta_j+\eta_{j-1})). \end{align} Then, one can show that \begin{align} f_\epsilon\rightarrow f,\quad \text{weakly}\quad as \quad \epsilon\downarrow 0. \end{align} That is to say \begin{align} \int_{0}^1f_\epsilon(\eta) d\mu(\eta)\rightarrow\int_0^1 f(\eta)d\mu(\eta). \end{align} In fact, by linearity of Lebesgue integral, we have \begin{align} \int_0^1f_\epsilon(\eta)d\mu(\eta)&=\sum_{\sigma=1}^M\int_{\xi_\sigma}^{\xi_{\sigma+1}}f_\epsilon(\eta)d\mu(\eta)\\ &\sim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\sum_{\sigma=1}^M \left((1+p_\sigma)\frac{\alpha_\sigma}{d_\sigma}+p_\sigma\frac{d_\sigma-\alpha_\sigma}{d_\sigma}\right)\mu([\xi_\sigma,\xi_{\sigma+1}])\\ &=\sum_{\sigma=1}^M \left(\frac{\alpha_\sigma}{d_\sigma}+p_\sigma\right)\mu([\xi_\sigma,\xi_{\sigma+1}])\\ &=\int_0^1 f(\eta)d\mu(\eta). \end{align} Then one can easily show that \begin{align} \Phi_\epsilon(m)\rightarrow\Phi(f_\epsilon). \end{align}

Now, if we set $f^*$ to be the (unique) minimizer of $\min_{f\in\mathcal{H}}\Phi(f)$, then by claim 1, we can find a sequence of $\Phi_\epsilon(m_\epsilon)$, such that

\begin{align} \lim_{\epsilon \downarrow 0}\Phi_\epsilon(m_\epsilon)=\Phi(f^*). \end{align}

Meanwhile, for any $\epsilon$, if $\Phi_\epsilon(m)$ assumes minimum at $m^*_\epsilon$, then we have

\begin{align} \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\Phi_\epsilon(m^*_\epsilon)\leq \Phi(f^*), \end{align}

in other words, we have

\begin{align} \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\left(\min_{m\in \mathbb{Z}^{N(\epsilon)}}\Phi_\epsilon(m)\right)\leq \min_{f\in \mathcal{H}}\Phi(f). \label{leq} \end{align}

Claim 2: For any $m_\epsilon\in \mathbb{Z}^{N(\epsilon)}$, there is $f_\epsilon\in \mathcal{H}$, such that \begin{align} \liminf_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\left(\Phi_{\epsilon}(m_\epsilon)-\Phi(f_\epsilon)\right)\geq 0. \end{align}

*Proof: * Fix $\epsilon$ and $m\in \mathbb{Z}^{N(\epsilon)}$, define a piece-wise integer-valued function $f_\epsilon$ as follows: \begin{align} f_\epsilon(\eta)=m_j,\quad \eta\in [\frac{1}{2}(\eta_{j+1}+\eta_{j}),\frac{1}{2}(\eta_j+\eta_{j-1})). \end{align} Then as $\epsilon\rightarrow 0$, we see that $\Phi_{\epsilon}(m)$ converges to \begin{align} \Phi(f_\epsilon)-\int_{0}^1\gamma(\eta)\phi(\eta){\frac{1}{4}-(f_\epsilon(\eta)-[f_\epsilon(\eta)]-\frac{1}{2})^2}d\eta, \end{align} that is to say \begin{align} \Phi_\epsilon(m)-\Phi(f_\epsilon)\rightarrow \int_{0}^1\gamma(\eta)\phi(\eta){\frac{1}{4}-(f_\epsilon(\eta)-[f_\epsilon(\eta)]-\frac{1}{2})^2}d\eta,\quad as\quad \epsilon\downarrow 0. (*) \end{align} Apparently, the right hand side (*) is non-negative, which implies that \begin{align} \liminf_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\left(\Phi_\epsilon(m)-\Phi(f_\epsilon)\right)\geq 0. \end{align}

To apply the claim 2, we split the sequence ${\Phi(f_\epsilon)}_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}$ into two subsequences:

$$ (1). \quad \{\Phi(f_\epsilon)|\Phi(f_\epsilon)\geq \Phi_\epsilon(m_\epsilon)\}_{\epsilon\downarrow 0} $$

$$ (2). \quad {\Phi(f_\epsilon)|\Phi(f_\epsilon)< \Phi_\epsilon(m_\epsilon)}_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}. $$

In the case (1), since $ \liminf_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\left(\Phi_{\epsilon}(m_\epsilon)-\Phi(f_\epsilon)\right)\geq 0$, we have

\begin{align} \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\Phi(f_\epsilon)=\lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\Phi_\epsilon(m^*_\epsilon), \end{align}

where we have chosen $m^*_\epsilon$ to be the minimizer for each fixed $\epsilon$. Thus, we have

\begin{align} \min_{f\in\mathcal{H}}\Phi(f)\leq \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\Phi(f_\epsilon)\leq \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\Phi_\epsilon(m^*_\epsilon) \end{align}

In the second case, we have $\Phi(f_\epsilon)< \Phi_\epsilon(m_\epsilon)$, if we choose $m_\epsilon$ to be the minimizer, then it immediately implies \begin{align} \min_{f\in\mathcal{H}}\Phi(f)\leq \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\left(\min_{m\in \mathbb{Z}^{N(\epsilon)}}\Phi_\epsilon(m)\right).\label{geq-2} \end{align}

Combine all above together, we have proved that \begin{align} \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\left(\min_{m\in \mathbb{Z}^{N(\epsilon)}}\Phi_\epsilon(m)\right)= \min_{f\in \mathcal{H}}\Phi(f). \end{align}

The variational equation

Recall the functional \begin{align} \Phi(f)=2<a\phi,f>+<\gamma \phi,f^2-(f-[f]-\frac{1}{2})^2+\frac{1}{4}>+<T(\phi f),\phi f>, \end{align} where $a,\gamma,\phi\in C[0,1]$, $\phi $ and $\gamma$ are strictly positive, $Tf(\eta)=\frac{1}{\pi}\int_0^1\tau(\eta,\mu)f(\mu)d\mu$ is a symmetric positive definite bounded operator in $L^2(0,1)$.

  1. Prove it is strictly convex, thus it attains its minimum value at a unique element in $\mathcal{H}={f\text{ measurable on } [0,1] :|\Phi(f)|<\infty}$
  2. Find the variational equations, which are \begin{align} a+T(\phi f)+\gamma[f]+\frac{1}{2}\gamma&=0,\quad if\quad f>[f]\\ a+T(\phi f)+\gamma[f]+\frac{1}{2}\gamma&\in [0,\gamma], \quad if\quad f=[f], \end{align} where $f=[f]+r,0\leq r<1.$
  3. Now consider the Green potential:\begin{align} T(\phi f)(\eta)=\frac{1}{\pi}\int_{0}^1\log{\left|\frac{\eta-\bar\mu}{\eta-\mu}\right|}f(\mu)\phi(\mu)d\mu, \end{align} How to construct a explicit solution to the variational equation?

As for the answer, we are still working on that.
